title: Minimum size of the field-corner gift
vignette: A land-owner has harvested most of his wheat and must now set aside a corner for the poor. May he leave the bare legal minimum (1⁄60) or is he expected to be more generous?

options.text: Give only 1⁄60 — owner may keep the rest.
Give a larger share, based on field size and local need.

title: Early vs. late designation of Pe’ah
vignette: The owner has already left some standing stalks at the field’s start but nothing at the end. Count those early stalks as the poor’s share or treat them as ownerless for anyone to take?

options.text: Count them as Pe’ah reserved for the poor (R. Shimon).
Treat them as hefker; even the rich may take (R. Yehudah).

title: Who gathers dangerous high fruit?
vignette: Dates hang high in a palm grove. Should the owner climb, cut the clusters and distribute them, or must the poor climb and pick for themselves?

options.text: Owner must harvest and hand out — safety first.
Let the poor harvest individually; owner needn’t intervene.

title: Grabbing all the gleanings
vignette: One pauper spreads his cloak over an un-collected pile to reserve everything for himself.

options.text: Let him keep what he covered — first come, first served.
Confiscate the pile and redistribute fairly (Mishnah ruling).

title: Scythes in the scramble
vignette: May the poor cut Pe’ah with sickles and spades, risking injury to one another?

options.text: Permit any tools; faster harvest for all.
Ban sharp tools; prevent harm among the poor.

title: How often may the poor enter a field?
vignette: Local leaders fix three daily collection times. Some poor people want free access all day.

options.text: Limit to three visits; prevents crowding and conflict (Rabban Gamliel).
Allow continuous entry; maximise the poor’s opportunity (R. Akiva).

title: Convert who harvested before converting
vignette: A non-Jew reaps his field, then converts to Judaism before bundling. Must he now leave sheaves for the poor?

options.text: Exempt — the reaping happened while he was a gentile (Tanna Kamma).
Obligate for the forgotten sheaf; duty attaches at binding (R. Yehudah).

title: Temple-dedicated crop later redeemed
vignette: Grain was declared Temple property and later redeemed by the owner. Are poor-people gifts still required?

options.text: Yes — after redemption, normal obligations resume.
No — at the crucial stage the grain belonged to the Temple and was exempt.

title: Setting Pe’ah aside for a named pauper
vignette: A volunteer harvests Pe’ah and says, “This is for Levi the pauper.” Does Levi acquire ownership automatically?

options.text: Yes — the collector acquires it on Levi’s behalf (R. Eliezer).
No — must give to the first poor person encountered (Sages).

title: Ownerless for poor only, or for everyone?
vignette: A farmer declares his crop ‘ownerless for the poor.’ Is that valid, or must hefker include the rich as well?

options.text: Valid — a partial hefker in favour of the poor works (Beit Shammai).
Invalid — hefker must be equal-access, rich or poor (Beit Hillel).

title: Oversized forgotten sheaf
vignette: All sheaves are one kab except one four-kab sheaf left behind. Does it count as ‘forgotten’ for the poor?

options.text: Not forgotten — owner keeps it (Beit Shammai).
Forgotten — poor may take it (Beit Hillel).

title: Sheaf left near obvious landmarks
vignette: A sheaf is left beside a stone wall or farm tools. Is it considered forgotten?

options.text: Not forgotten — owner intended to return (Beit Shammai).
Forgotten — poor may take it (Beit Hillel).

title: ‘Two or three’ rule for small bundles
vignette: How many forgotten sheaves, berries or flax-stalks trigger the poor’s right?

options.text: Two belong to the poor; three revert to owner (Beit Hillel).
Three to poor; four to owner (Beit Shammai).

title: Two small sheaves totalling a full measure
vignette: Two forgotten bundles together equal two se’ah (a full stack). Who owns them?

options.text: Owner keeps them (Rabban Gamliel).
Poor take them (Sages).

title: Scattered plots between olive trees
vignette: Small wheat plots lie between rows of olives. Leave one corner from each tiny plot or treat the whole area as one field?

options.text: Give Pe’ah from every plot (Beit Shammai).
One Pe’ah for them all (Beit Hillel).

title: Striped harvesting pattern
vignette: Farmer mows the field in stripes, leaving moist stalks between. Does each moist patch need its own Pe’ah?

options.text: Yes; each stripe counts separately (R. Akiva).
No; one Pe’ah satisfies the lot (Sages).

title: Harvesting fresh onions vs. storing dry
vignette: Owner pulls fresh onions to sell now but leaves the rest to dry for storage. Is Pe’ah required twice?

options.text: Two separate Pe’ahs – each harvest is distinct.
Single Pe’ah on the final remainder.

title: Seed-onion exemption
vignette: Are seed-onions liable to Pe’ah, and does an onion plot between vegetables need Pe’ah for each sub-plot?

options.text: Liable; each onion patch must give (Sages).
Exempt; or only one combined Pe’ah (R. Jose).

title: Brothers divide then re-partner
vignette: Two brothers split the inherited field. Do they each leave Pe’ah separately? Later they farm together again—now what?

options.text: After division, each must give; after re-partnership, just one Pe’ah.
Always one Pe’ah—treat estate continuity as overriding.

title: Minimum plot size liable for Pe’ah
vignette: How small can a field be yet still owe a corner to the poor? Measures range from ‘six by six handbreadths’ to ‘any size’.

options.text: Only sizeable plots (various larger minima).
Even the tiniest patch is liable (R. Akiva).

title: Gleaning stalk mixed into owner’s pile
vignette: A leket stalk falls into the harvest pile. May the owner swap in another stalk (after tithing) or must he hand over the original?

options.text: Swap permitted—owner keeps his pile (R. Eliezer).
No swap—return the very stalk to the poor (Sages).
